question: What is the role of calcium oscillations in VDAC1 gating, and does the frequency of mitochondrial calcium uptake encode information about cell fate? Specifically: (1) VDAC1 is voltage-gated and calcium-permeable — do physiological calcium oscillations (0.1-10 Hz) open and close VDAC1 rhythmically, creating a pulsatile metabolite flux? (2) Does the frequency of calcium transients determine whether VDAC1 stays monomeric (survival) or oligomerizes (death) — is there a frequency threshold? (3) How does the MCU (mitochondrial calcium uniporter) on the IMM coordinate with VDAC1 on the OMM to create a two-gate calcium filter? (4) Do cancer cells show altered calcium oscillation frequencies that keep VDAC1 in the monomeric state, and is this another mechanism of gate-jamming beyond HK-II/Bcl-xL/cholesterol? (5) Can calcium oscillation frequency be a therapeutic target — could pacing mitochondrial calcium uptake shift VDAC1 toward the oligomeric (pro-apoptotic) state in cancer?

gate.recommendation: Lab Gate PASSED with filter. 8/21 claims cleared. 13 filtered: 'Pacing mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uptake (e.g., via optoge...' not feasible; 'VDAC1 is Ca²⁺-permeable and its conductance is mod...' lacks falsifiability; 'VDAC1 is Ca²⁺-permeable and its conductance is mod...' not feasible

hypotheses.prediction: IF reconstituted VDAC1 in planar lipid bilayers is exposed to sinusoidal Ca²⁺ waveforms (0.1–10 Hz, amplitude 0.1–10 µM), THEN single-channel open probability (Po) will oscillate in phase with Ca²⁺ at ≤1 Hz (coherence >0.7) but lose phase-locking at >5 Hz (coherence <0.3), with the channel adopting a time-averaged intermediate conductance (~60% of full open state).
IF isolated mitochondria are exposed to Ca²⁺ pulses of identical total integral (e.g., 50 µM·s) but different frequencies (0.2 Hz vs. 2 Hz vs. constant), THEN the 2 Hz

IF cytosolic Ca²⁺ oscillations are delivered at varying frequencies (0.1–10 Hz) to intact cells expressing genetically encoded Ca²⁺ indicators in cytosol, IMS, and matrix, THEN IMS [Ca²⁺] will track cytosolic oscillations near-linearly (gain ~0.8 at 0.5 Hz), but matrix [Ca²⁺] will show nonlinear bandpass behavior: attenuated at <0.1 Hz (efflux-dominated) and >3 Hz (MCU cannot activate between pulses), with peak transmission at 0.3–1 Hz, where IMS microdomains transiently exceed MCU Kd (~10–20 µM).

protocols.prediction: IF reconstituted VDAC1 in planar lipid bilayers is exposed to sinusoidal Ca²⁺ waveforms (0.1–10 Hz, amplitude 0.1–10 µM), THEN single-channel open probability (Po) will oscillate in phase with Ca²⁺ at ≤1 Hz (coherence >0.7) but lose phase-locking at >5 Hz (coherence <0.3), with the channel adopting a time-averaged intermediate conductance (~60% of full open state).
protocols.protocol: Reconstitute purified human VDAC1 into DPhPC planar bilayers. Use a piezo-driven perfusion system (Bhatt et al. rapid-exchange method) to deliver defined Ca²⁺ waveforms (0.1, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 10 Hz; 1 µM peak) while recording single-channel currents at ±30 mV with Axopatch 200B. Analyze Po power spectra and stimulus-response coherence. Timeline: 8 weeks.
readouts: ATP flux (luciferase assay in vesicle system)
protocols.expected_outcome: Po power spectrum shows peak at stimulus frequency for ≤1 Hz; peak disappears at >5 Hz with Po converging to ~0.5–0.6. Metabolite flux (measured by ATP/ADP transport in vesicle assays) shows pulsatile release at 0.5 Hz but steady-state at 10 Hz.
protocols.null_outcome: No frequency-dependent difference in coherence; VDAC1 gating is Ca²⁺-insensitive or tracks all frequencies equally. Alternatively, no gating response to Ca²⁺ at any frequency.

protocols.prediction: IF isolated mitochondria are exposed to Ca²⁺ pulses of identical total integral (e.g., 50 µM·s) but different frequencies (0.2 Hz vs. 2 Hz vs. constant), THEN the 2 Hz
protocols.protocol: Isolate liver/HeLa mitochondria by differential centrifugation. Deliver Ca²⁺ pulses via microinjector into respiring mitochondria (succinate + rotenone) at 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5 Hz, matched for total Ca²⁺ integral (50 µM·s). Monitor matrix Ca²⁺ (Rhod-2 AM), membrane potential (TMRM). After 10-min protocols, cross-link with EGS, run BN-PAGE and SDS-PAGE for VDAC1 oligomers (anti-VDAC1 ab), and ELISA for cytochrome c in supernatant. Include ±CGP-37157 (NCLX inhibitor) and ±CsA (mPTP inhibitor). Timeline: 10 weeks.
protocols.expected_outcome: At matched integral, 2 Hz produces progressive matrix Ca²⁺ elevation (staircase pattern, final >20 µM) while 0.2 Hz allows full efflux between pulses (sawtooth, final <5 µM). VDAC1 oligomer:monomer ratio increases sharply above ~1–2 Hz. CGP-37157 shifts threshold leftward (oligomerization at lower frequencies). CsA blocks oligomerization at all frequencies.
protocols.null_outcome: Oligomerization depends only on total Ca²⁺ integral regardless of frequency. Matrix Ca²⁺ returns to baseline between pulses at all frequencies. No frequency threshold exists.

protocols.prediction: IF cytosolic Ca²⁺ oscillations are delivered at varying frequencies (0.1–10 Hz) to intact cells expressing genetically encoded Ca²⁺ indicators in cytosol, IMS, and matrix, THEN IMS [Ca²⁺] will track cytosolic oscillations near-linearly (gain ~0.8 at 0.5 Hz), but matrix [Ca²⁺] will show nonlinear bandpass behavior: attenuated at <0.1 Hz (efflux-dominated) and >3 Hz (MCU cannot activate between pulses), with peak transmission at 0.3–1 Hz, where IMS microdomains transiently exceed MCU Kd (~10–20 µM).
protocols.protocol: HeLa cells co-expressing CEPIA3mt (matrix), LAR-GECO1.2-IMS (IMS-targeted), and jRCaMP1b (cytosol). Drive Ca²⁺ oscillations using OptoSTIM1 (blue light-activated STIM1) at defined frequencies (0.05, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 1, 3, 5, 10 Hz). Image all three compartments simultaneously with spinning-disk confocal at 20 Hz. Repeat ±VDAC1 knockdown (siRNA), ±MCU knockdown (siRNA), ±Ru360, ±VBIT-4 (VDAC1 oligomerization inhibitor). Compute transfer functions (cytosol→IMS, IMS→matrix) at each frequency. Timeline: 14 weeks.
protocols.expected_outcome: Cytosol→IMS transfer function is relatively flat (low-pass, cutoff ~5 Hz). IMS→matrix transfer function shows bandpass: gain peaks at 0.3–1 Hz, drops at <0.1 Hz and >3 Hz. MCU knockdown abolishes matrix uptake at all frequencies. VDAC1 knockdown reduces IMS peak [Ca²⁺] below MCU threshold, collapsing matrix uptake. VBIT-4 has minimal effect on Ca²⁺ transfer (affects oligomerization, not conductance).
protocols.null_outcome: Matrix Ca²⁺ tracks cytosolic oscillations linearly at all frequencies (no bandpass). IMS [Ca²⁺] never exceeds MCU Kd. VDAC1 knockdown has no effect on IMS Ca²⁺ dynamics.

final_claims.statement: VDAC1 gating kinetics (~1–10 ms transitions) are fast enough to partially track Ca²⁺ oscillations at 0.1–1 Hz, but at >5 Hz, VDAC1 effectively time-averages the signal, remaining in a partially open state rather than cycling fully open/closed.
final_claims.mechanism: VDAC1 voltage-dependent gating occurs on ms timescales in bilayers, but cytoplasmic Ca²⁺ oscillations modulate local [Ca²⁺] over 100ms–10s periods, creating frequency-dependent filtering.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Single-channel recordings of VDAC1 in reconstituted membranes exposed to defined Ca²⁺ waveforms at 0.1–10 Hz showing no frequency-dependent gating differences.

final_claims.statement: VDAC1 oligomerization is driven by cumulative matrix Ca²⁺ overload rather than directly by oscillation frequency — but frequency encodes the *rate* of matrix accumulation, so a frequency threshold (~1–2 Hz sustained) effectively exists above which oligomerization probability sharply increases.
final_claims.mechanism: High-frequency Ca²⁺ pulses exceed mitochondrial Ca²⁺ efflux capacity (NCLX), causing progressive matrix Ca²⁺ accumulation → mPTP sensitization → VDAC1 oligomerization via conformational changes/cytochrome c release.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Demonstrating that total Ca²⁺ load, not frequency, determines oligomerization when integral is matched across different frequency protocols.

final_claims.statement: VDAC1-MCU form a two-gate filter where VDAC1 (low selectivity, high conductance, Kd ~0.5 mM) gates bulk Ca²⁺ entry into the IMS, while MCU (high selectivity, Kd ~10–20 μM, cooperative Hill ~3–4) acts as a nonlinear threshold detector — together creating bandpass filtering of Ca²⁺ signals.
final_claims.mechanism: IMS Ca²⁺ microdomains at VDAC1-MCU contact points reach ~10–20 μM during oscillations, exceeding MCU's activation threshold only during peak phases, creating pulsatile matrix uptake.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Showing IMS [Ca²⁺] at VDAC1-MCU junctions never exceeds MCU Kd during physiological oscillations.

final_claims.statement: Cancer cells remodel Ca²⁺ oscillation machinery (IP3R, SERCA, STIM/Orai) to reduce oscillation amplitude and increase frequency irregularity, maintaining VDAC1 in monomeric state — this represents a distinct gate-jamming mechanism complementary to HK-II binding.
final_claims.mechanism: complementary to HK-II binding.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Comprehensive Ca²⁺ imaging in matched cancer/normal cells showing no systematic difference in mitochondrial Ca²⁺ oscillation parameters. ───

final_claims.statement: Physiological Ca²⁺ oscillations (0.1–10 Hz) rhythmically gate VDAC1, producing pulsatile metabolite flux.
final_claims.mechanism: VDAC1’s voltage-dependent gating is modulated by Ca²⁺ binding (EF-hand-like motifs), causing conformational shifts that transiently open/close the pore in sync with cytosolic Ca²⁺ spikes.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Patch-clamp recordings of VDAC1 in lipid bilayers showing no gating response to 0.1–10 Hz Ca²⁺ pulses, or metabolomics data showing no rhythmic flux of ATP/ADP/ROS.

final_claims.statement: Ca²⁺ transient frequency determines VDAC1 oligomerization state, with a threshold (~1–5 Hz) favoring apoptosis via oligomerization.
final_claims.mechanism: plausible)
final_claims.falsifiable_by: FRET or cross-linking assays showing no frequency-dependent oligomerization in isolated mitochondria, or in vivo data where Ca²⁺ clamping at 1–5 Hz fails to induce apoptosis.

final_claims.statement: VDAC1 and MCU act as a "two-gate" Ca²⁺ filter, where VDAC1’s OMM gating sets the amplitude and MCU’s IMM uptake shapes the frequency response.
final_claims.mechanism: VDAC1’s voltage/ligand gating controls Ca²⁺ entry into the intermembrane space, while MCU’s cooperative Ca²⁺ binding (Hill coefficient >1) integrates these signals, filtering low-amplitude/high-frequency noise.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Simultaneous Ca²⁺ imaging in cytosol/IMM showing no frequency-dependent attenuation of signals, or MCU knockout failing to disrupt VDAC1-mediated Ca²⁺ oscillations.

final_claims.statement: Cancer cells exhibit altered Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies (e.g., sustained low-frequency spikes) to maintain VDAC1 in a monomeric, pro-survival state, independent of HK-II/Bcl-xL/cholesterol.
final_claims.mechanism: Oncogenic signaling (e.g., PI3K/AKT) may dampen IP₃R-mediated Ca²⁺ release, reducing oscillation frequency and locking VDAC1 in a monomeric state that supports Warburg metabolism.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Single-cell Ca²⁺ imaging in cancer vs. normal cells showing no frequency differences, or VDAC1 oligomerization assays in cancer cells showing no correlation with oscillation frequency.

final_claims.statement: Pacing mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uptake (e.g., via optogenetics or pharmacological modulators) can shift VDAC1 toward oligomerization and apoptosis in cancer, with a therapeutic index >10.
final_claims.mechanism: Forced high-frequency Ca²⁺ transients (e.g., 5 Hz) may override cancer’s endogenous low-frequency signals, inducing VDAC1 oligomerization and cytochrome c release.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: In vivo models showing no apoptosis induction at therapeutic doses, or off-target toxicity (e.g., cardiac arrhythmias) at <10x effective dose. --- ───

final_claims.statement: VDAC1 is Ca²⁺-permeable and its conductance is modulated by physiological [Ca²⁺] (μM range), but gating kinetics (~ms) allow rhythmic response to 0.1-10 Hz oscillations, creating pulsatile IMS Ca²⁺/metabolite flux.
final_claims.mechanism: Ca²⁺ binds VDAC1 C-terminus, stabilizing open state at low [Ca²⁺] and promoting closure/flux modulation at peaks.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Patch-clamp on isolated mito showing no P_open oscillation at 0.1-10 Hz sinusoidal [Ca²⁺]_ext.

final_claims.statement: High-frequency Ca²⁺ oscillations (>1-2 Hz) promote VDAC1 oligomerization (pro-death) vs. low-frequency (<0.5 Hz, survival) via sustained IMS/matrix Ca²⁺ overload, with ~1 Hz threshold.
final_claims.mechanism: Freq-dependent MCU rectification amplifies matrix Ca²⁺ at high f, triggering ROS/PTP that stabilizes VDAC1 oligomers.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: VDAC1 oligomer assays (BN-PAGE) in MCU-KO cells showing no freq-dependent shift.

final_claims.statement: VDAC1/MCU form a two-gate filter: VDAC1 permits cytosolic Ca²⁺ bursts to IMS (rate-limited by voltage/Ca²⁺ gating); MCU rectifies high-freq bursts for matrix uptake (K_d ~1-20 μM, Hill n>1).
final_claims.mechanism: Spatial proximity (~10 nm) and MICU1/2 sensing ensure MCU activates only at peak [Ca²⁺]_IMS >5 μM from VDAC1.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Super-res EM or FRAP showing no VDAC1-MCU co-localization/flux coupling.

final_claims.statement: Cancer cells exhibit lower Ca²⁺ oscillation freq. (0.1-0.5 Hz vs. 1-5 Hz normal), stabilizing monomeric VDAC1, additive to HK-II/Bcl-xL jamming.
final_claims.mechanism: Upregulated PMCA/SERCA pumps dampen freq., preventing Ca²⁺ overload-induced oligomerization.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Live-cell imaging in matched normal/cancer lines showing no freq. difference.

final_claims.statement: Pacing mito Ca²⁺ uptake freq. (>2 Hz) is viable therapeutic target to oligomerize VDAC1 in cancer (safety index >10 if selective), superior to CBD (Kd=11 μM, window 1-10 μM but CYP3A4 IC50=1 μM).
final_claims.mechanism: Opto/genetic MCU pacing (e.g., opto-MCU) forces high-freq uptake, bypassing cancer-damped signals.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Freq.-paced MCF7 cells (dox IC50=0.5 μM benchmark) showing no apoptosis shift vs. vehicle. ───

final_claims.statement: VDAC1 gating is fast enough to follow physiological calcium oscillations, creating a pulsatile flux of both Ca2+ and metabolites across the outer mitochondrial membrane.
final_claims.mechanism: The rapid influx of Ca2+ ions through the VDAC1 pore alters the local transmembrane potential, and since VDAC1's voltage-gating operates on a millisecond timescale, it can rhythmically open and close in sync with sub-10 Hz signals.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Single-channel patch-clamp recordings of VDAC1 in a reconstituted lipid bilayer showing no change in open probability (Pₒ) when exposed to oscillating calcium gradients at 1-10 Hz.

final_claims.statement: A sustained, high-frequency (>1 Hz) mitochondrial Ca2+ signal is required to trigger VDAC1 oligomerization, while low-frequency (<0.1 Hz) signals permit relaxation to the monomeric state.
final_claims.mechanism: High-frequency pulses cause cumulative, incomplete conformational relaxation in VDAC1 monomers, progressively exposing interaction domains that lead to irreversible oligomerization and pore formation.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Super-resolution microscopy (dSTORM/PALM) of mitochondria showing VDAC1 oligomerization is dependent only on the integrated Ca2+ load (total concentration over time), not the signal frequency.

final_claims.statement: The coordination of low-affinity VDAC1 and high-affinity MCU creates a band-pass filter, allowing mitochondria to respond to large, rapid Ca2+ spikes while ignoring small, slow fluctuations.
final_claims.mechanism: VDAC1 passes high-amplitude Ca2+ signals into the intermembrane space, creating a localized pool that is then efficiently taken up by the high-affinity MCU, effectively filtering for salient signals.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Direct measurement of intermembrane space Ca2+ showing its concentration profile is a simple, non-filtered reflection of cytosolic Ca2+ dynamics. ───

final_claims.statement: Physiological Ca²⁺ oscillations (0.1–10 Hz) can rhythmically modulate VDAC1 gating, creating pulsatile metabolite flux.
final_claims.mechanism: Cytosolic Ca²⁺ binds to VDAC1, altering its voltage-dependent gating kinetics on a timescale matching oscillation periods.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Direct patch-clamp of VDAC1 in intact mitochondria showing no change in open probability when challenged with physiological-frequency Ca²⁺ pulses.

final_claims.statement: A high-frequency threshold of mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uptake promotes VDAC1 oligomerization and apoptosis.
final_claims.mechanism: Sustained high-frequency Ca²⁺ pulses cause localized OMM lipid peroxidation or conformational strain, driving VDAC1 oligomerization and cytochrome c release.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Demonstrating that forced high-frequency Ca²⁺ oscillations do not increase VDAC1 oligomers or apoptosis in cells lacking MCU.

final_claims.statement: Cancer cells can evade apoptosis by maintaining Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies below the VDAC1 oligomerization threshold.
final_claims.mechanism: Altered ER-mitochondria coupling or upregulated Ca²⁺ buffers limit mitochondrial Ca²⁺ transient frequency, keeping VDAC1 monomeric and non-apoptotic.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Showing that cancer cells with known apoptosis resistance have higher, not lower, mitochondrial Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies.

final_claims.statement: Therapeutically pacing mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uptake (e.g., via optogenetic MCU) can shift VDAC1 to an oligomeric, pro-apoptotic state.
final_claims.mechanism: Forced high-frequency Ca²⁺ entry via MCU creates a local OMM microenvironment that favors VDAC1-VDAC1 interactions.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Pacing fails to induce VDAC1 oligomers or apoptosis even when combined with metabolic stress. ───
